items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall on the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon, Dauntsey Brook due to rainfall. River levels are falling, but the risk of flooding to roads in Reybridge remains.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
We will continue to monitor levels closely as further light rainfall is forecast tomorrow morning.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 01:00 PM on 14/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

The River Lavant is high, following a wet autumn. Minor flooding will continue to affect fields, gardens and roads including at Sheepwash Lane, Pook Lane and the Green In East Lavant. At The Sadlers in Westhampnett, the river will be high, but should remain lower than it has been over the past week. River flooding should not affect Chichester City Centre. Very little rain is forecast in the next five days. River levels might rise a centimetre or two, until Friday, as groundwater is still rising. Flood impacts should not increase significantly this week. From the weekend river levels should fall a few centimetres. The river will be sensitive to any additional rainfall over the rest of winter. If you see a blockage affecting the flow in the river, please call our incident hotline on 0800 80 70 60. We are operating the River Lavant Flood Alleviation scheme to reduce the flood risk. We will update this message by 12:00 14/12/2023.

River levels remain high at the Sandhurst river gauge following recent heavy rainfall. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads on both sides of the river from Tewkesbury to Quedgeley, Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore. Severn Ham, Tewkesbury starts to fill. 

Predicted peaks:- Mythe 4.0m to 4.3m Saturday morning 16/12/2023, Haw Bridge 4.9m to 5.2m Saturday morning 16/12/2023, Sandhurst 3.2m to 3.5m on-going, Gloucester 3.2m to 3.5m on-going. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10am on 14/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 18:00, Wednesday 13/12/23, or as the situation changes.

The Upper River Aire Flood Alert has been removed as river levels continue to fall below levels of concern. Washlands in the Skipton area will slowly empty over the next few days. We continue to monitor the forecast and will reissue the alert if necessary.

River levels remain high on the Upper River Ouse due to recent rainfall. The river level at the York Viking recorder has peaked and will continue to fall, remaining high on Wednesday 13 December 2023.
Areas at risk include riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and to the south as far as Naburn Lock, including King's Staith, Queen's Staith and South Esplanade. Flood Warnings in central York remain in place, but the previously issued flood warning at Fulford has been removed.  
We continue to monitor levels closely. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 20:00hrs on Wednesday 13/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ouse at York - St George's Field and Queen's Staith
items.message:
River levels remain high on the upper River Ouse due to recent rainfall. The river level at the York Viking recorder is currently 3.7m and falling. Levels will remain high on Wednesday 13/12/2023. 
Flooding is affecting locations near the River Ouse, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Queen's Staith, on South Esplanade, Friar's Terrace and Tower Place, St George's Field car park and Rowntree Park. 
Our riverside defences remain in place, and the Foss Barrier is in operation. Our incident room is open and we continue to monitor the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Please monitor local water levels and weather conditions and put your flood plan into action. 
This message will be updated by 20:00hrs on Wednesday 13/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower Dorset Frome, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Dorchester and Wareham. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk, cycle or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 14/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Bridgnorth, Buildwas, Crew Green, Montford and Welshbridge river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge and Bridgnorth and access to properties along Riverside in Bridgnorth. Updated predicted peaks:- Crew Green predicted to peak between 5.7m and 5.9m Wednesday PM, 13/12/23. Montford predicted to peak between 5.2m to 5.5m overnight, Wednesday 13/12/23. Welshbridge predicted to peak between 2.8m to 3.1m Thursday AM, 14/12/23. Buildwas predicted to peak between 4.2m to 4.6m Thursday PM, 14/12/23. Bridgnorth predicted to peak between 3.4m to 3.8m Thursday PM, 14/12/23. We expect river levels to remain high. Frankwell phase 1 barriers have been deployed. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 10:00am Thursday 14/12/23, or as the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.37m and falling slowly. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45m. The drain level at Currymoor is stable at 6.64m. 

Further isolated showers are possible on Wednesday before a band of light rain crosses the area on Thursday morning. Drier weather is forecast for the remainder of the week.

We are currently pumping at Currymoor, Northmoor and Saltmoor stations and will maximise pumping operations as and when river levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel is also being used to evacuate water away from the Parrett-Tone confluence. We will continue to monitor rainfall and river levels closely, and our staff are checking flood defences.

Please remain mindful of weather conditions, local water levels, and use your flood plan if you have one. Do not attempt to drive, walk or cycle through flood water.

This message will be updated by midday on Thursday 14/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message:
Groundwater levels at all sites across the Chase have continued to rise overnight. Flooding of minor roads across the area is expected, with the Upper Tarrant valley, The Gussage at Minchington 
 and the road across Wyke Down to Monkton up Wimborne worst affected. Householders with pumps and other property level resilience measures should deploy them now. Avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave can damage adjacent property and may put your own and emergency responders lives at risk. This message will be updated on Thursday 14th December or as the situation changes.

We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. items.description: The Rivers Blyth and Walpole and Chediston, Bramfield and Wrentham watercourses
items.message: River levels are now returning to normal. The forecast is for no significant rainfall for the next few days. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

The Western Rother is high and rising at Fittleworth. Flood impacts affecting fields, roads and gardens will continue. The Western Rother could rise another 10cm at Fittleworth, before beginning to fall by 17:00 13/12/2023. By Wednesday evening, water will be closer to Fittleworth Mill and nearby properties. Flood water is currently also close to isolated mill properties at Lodsbridge near Selham, as well as affecting roads and fields in that vicinity. Very little rain is forecast in the next five days. The Western Rother in Liss, Iping and Midhurst is already falling and near a normal level. River levels have peaked at our Lodsbridge gauge and should slowly fall through Wednesday, falling significantly by Thursday. In Fittleworth flood impacts should ease from the weekend. Water levels will remain sensitive to additional rainfall over the next few weeks. Early actions to reduce potential impacts at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth are encouraged. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 12:00 14/12/2023.

River levels are remaining high in the Middle Hampshire Avon and its Tributaries due to the heavy rainfall in the last week and additional significant contributions to river flow from rising groundwater levels. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Salisbury and Ringwood. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 15/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

The Aldingbourne Rife is high and slowly rising through Bersted. Flood water will continue to affect land and caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre, parts of the car park at Tescos on Shripney Road, fields near Shripney Lane, and be close to properties on Durban Road, Bersted. In Barnham, river levels are falling nearer to normal and any flood impacts should be minimal. Very little rain is forecast in the next five days. The Aldingbourne Rife should begin to slowly fall from 10:00 13/12/2023. Flood impacts could remain until the middle of next week (20/12/2023). The Aldingbourne Rife might not return nearer to normal until the new year. Water levels will remain sensitive to any additional rain in December. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Barnham, if you have them. We are clearing grilles through Barnham, and our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 12:00 14/12/2023.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Wednesday 13th December and for the next few days. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to the natural tide locking effect. Tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, restricts the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message on Thursday 14th December, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message:
River levels remain high on the Tidal River Ouse due to heavy rainfall in the Upper Ouse and the effects of tides. However, river levels are falling. Flooding may be affecting locations near the River Ouse and tidal areas of the River Wharfe, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around the tidal foreshore and agricultural land adjacent to the river in the Cawood, Kelfield, Wistow and Selby areas. A flood warning remains in force at Ryther on the River Wharfe. 
River levels will remain high on Wednesday 13/12/2023 due to the combined influence of high levels upstream and the effect of tides, with levels expected to remain high but falling slowly over the coming days. Low lying land may continue to be affected by flooding even as river levels fall. We will continue to monitor the river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. 
This message will be updated by 20:00hrs on Wednesday 13/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels remain high on the upper River Ouse due to recent rainfall. The river level at the York Viking recorder is currently 3.7m and falling. The river will remain high but continue falling on Wednesday 13/12/2023. 
Flooding continues to affect locations near the River Ouse with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around King's Staith in York and riverside areas through York from Lendal Bridge to Millennium Bridge. 
Our riverside defences remain in place and the Foss Barrier is in operation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Please monitor local water levels and weather conditions and put your flood plan into action. Our incident room is open and we continue to monitor the forecast. 
This message will be updated by 20:00hrs on Wednesday 13/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

Further rain and showers are forecast for today, but this should clear overnight, Thursday is forecast to be mostly dry. We expect river levels to remain high and sensitive to further rainfall for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. items.description: The River Waveney from Diss and the River Dove to Ellingham, including Bungay
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Wednesday 13th December 2023. We are currently seeing higher river levels than normal in the area of Diss.  We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for continued unsettled weather over the next couple of days. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message on Thursday 14th December, or as the situation changes.

The water level in the Eastern Yar remains very high. At Alverstone the level is falling with no rain recorded in the past 12 hours at Knighton. At Sandown the level is stable and expected to fall slowly over the next few hours. Today (Wednesday 13/12/23), a continuation of flooding affecting land, access and cycle tracks, gardens and roads (Golf Links and Moreton Common Road) throughout the Yar Valley is expected. A band of light rain is forecast tomorrow morning (Thursday 14/12/23), with no more than 2mm expected. The weather outlook to Sunday looks fairly dry, so after today, the water level will continue to fall for the next 5 days. The tidal range at Bembridge has also increased, allowing more water to drain to sea. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please ensure that any products used to protect gardens from flooding can operate and avoid flooded areas. This message will be updated or removed by 17:00 on Thursday 14/12/23.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to rainfall over the past few weeks and remain high at our observation borehole in Draycot Foliat in the Og Valley area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and remain at a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater over the coming weeks. 

The groundwater level at Draycot Foliat is higher than normal for this time of year and is currently very slowly rising.  The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and groundwater levels and may start to rise again if there is further rainfall. Low-lying land, gardens, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding.  Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 15/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.19m and falling. 

The pumping station drain level is 8.52m and starting to fall very slowly. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.30m, from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86m, and from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93m. Property flooding is possible with this level exceeding 8.35m. For up-to-date water levels visit the gauge section of our website (check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/station/3379).

We are currently pumping at Huish Episcopi and Westover stations and will continue to maximise pumping operations as river levels allow. Scattered showers are forecast today with a band of light rain on Thursday morning. We expect dry weather for the remainder of the week.

Please remain mindful of weather conditions and local water levels, and do not attempt to drive, cycle or walk through flood water. Please refer to @TravelSomerset for information on closed roads.

This message will be updated by midday on 14/12/23, or as the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.37m and falling slowly. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45m. The drain level at Currymoor is stable at 6.64m.

Further isolated showers are possible on Wednesday before a band of light rain crosses the area on Thursday morning. Drier weather is forecast for the remainder of the week.

We are currently pumping at Currymoor, Northmoor and Saltmoor stations and will maximise pumping operations as and when river levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel is also being used to evacuate water away from the Parrett-Tone confluence. We will continue to monitor rainfall and river levels closely, and our staff are checking flood defences.

Please remain mindful of weather conditions, local water levels, and your flood plan if you have one. Do not attempt to drive, walk or cycle through flood water.

This message will be updated by midday on Thursday 14/12/23, or as the situation changes.

Surface water issues around the square in Stamford Bridge have now reduced. 
Further light rainfall is forecast today, Wednesday 13/12/2023. Our incident room is open and we are monitoring rainfall and river levels, managing flood defences, pumping and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. items.message:
The River Parrett and River Yeo remain high upstream of Langport. The River Yeo is returning to normal winter levels at Ilchester and Pen Mill. Flood water remains on large areas of the Somerset Moors around Mulchelney and Langport, and adjacent to the Sowy River. Areas most at risk include the Ilchester to Yeovilton road at the end of the runway, the Mudford to Limington road, and the road at the south end of Westover Trading Estate. 

Scattered showers are forecast today with a band of light rain on Thursday morning. We expect dry weather for the remainder of the week. We are currently pumping at Westover and Huish Episcopi and will continue to maximise pumping activities as and when river levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel is also being used.

We are monitoring the situation closely. Please consider local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses. Do not attempt to walk, cycle, or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by midday on Thursday 14/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels on the River Rye remain high due to recent persistent rainfall. Rivers have responded to this rainfall falling on already wet catchments. Areas most at risk include low lying land around the River Rye and its tributaries, particularly around Ness and also including Ralsdale Beck, River Seph, Ledge Beck, Fangdale Beck, Prodale Beck, Ladhill Beck, Etton Gill, Borough Beck, Spittle Beck, and including properties at Salton, Nunnington and Helmsley. 
We continue to monitor levels closely. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 03:00am on Thursday 14/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

Large waves and sea spray are expected to affect the seafront as a result of strong winds, between 5:30pm and 7:45pm for this evenings tide, Wednesday 13 December. Areas most at risk are around Hunstanton seafront. Flood gates in the area will be closed by the Local Authority which will make access difficult. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of 3.71mAODN at 6:16pm, on Wednesday 13 December, which is 0.23m above tide tables, wind Force 6, North Easterly (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). The following tide on Thursday at 1:10am is currently forecast to be below the Alert threshold. Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. Our workforce are out checking flood defences. We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Thursday 14 December.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Wednesday 13th December and for the next few days. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to the natural tide locking effect. Tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, restricts the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation.  We will update this message on Thursday 14th December, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.71mAOD at 02:15 on 13/12/23 and 4.82mAOD at 14:15 on 13/12/23.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is high for this time of year at 210 cubic metres per second and is rising. We anticipate the flows to remain high for the nextfew days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 20:00 on 13/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the combination of high tides and waves forecast between 17:00hrs and 19:00hrs on Wednesday, 13/12/2023.
Areas most at risk include the North Sea coast from Mappleton to Spurn Point, including Spurn Road. Tides are approaching springs, and the weather outlook for the next few days is more settled with no further impacts currently forecast. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert over the coming days if necessary.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 20:30hrs on 13/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

In Hambledon, groundwater levels are high and rising. Since Friday 08/12/2023, 41mm of rain has been recorded at Worlds End, and the groundwater level at Whitedale Farm has risen by 2.63m. Groundwater is currently affecting the cellars of a small number of properties on Lower West and East Street. The football pitch is also being affected by a mixture of sewage and groundwater. The weather from today (13/12/2023) until Sunday (17/12/2023) is forecast to be dry. Groundwater levels in the village are expected to continue rising until the middle of next week. It is likely that more properties will be affected by cellar flooding on West Street and East Street during this time. We are liaising with Hambledon Flood Action Group. Please remove any valuables from cellars, and if you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 20/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle
items.message: In Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle, groundwater levels are high and rising. Since 08/12/2023, 36mm of rain has been recorded at Walderton, and the groundwater level in Finchdean has risen by 26cm. The Idsworth and Chalton Lavants are now flowing. Pumps which prevent water from entering property will be required for a small number of properties in Finchdean. Over the next 5 days, the weather is forecast to be dry. Groundwater levels in all villages are expected to rise for at least a week. In the next few days, it is possible that road flooding could begin to affect all villages, and cellar flooding could start to impact properties in Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle. Surface water flooding may occur during heavier rain events. We are liaising with the Flood Action Group. Please remove valuables from cellars, and ensure pumps used to reduce water levels can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 20/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to the recent rainfall across the area and have risen at our observation borehole in Longacre in the Lambourn Valley. Groundwater levels are higher than normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected within the next few days by flooding from groundwater.

The groundwater level at Longacre is higher than normal for this time of year but is currently very slowly declining. The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and groundwater levels and may start to rise again if there is further rainfall. Low-lying land, gardens, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 15/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

The risk of flooding from the River Witham has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

River levels remain high in the River Witham area following recent persistent rainfall. Further heavy rain is not forecast for the next few days, however, we expect river levels to remain high. Flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to rivers. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weed screens. Areas also at risk on the peak of the high tide are Church Laneham, Sutton on Trent to Normanton, Low Marnham to High Marnham, Sturton Road at Cottam Litton, Grassthorpe Road, the A1133 near Girton, the A57 at Dunham and A156 Gainsborough road. We expect river levels to peak after high tide today, 13/12/23 then start to fall. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.

Please avoid contact with flood water and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

River levels in Crowhurst and Bulverhythe are slowly falling. Minor flood impacts affecting fields, Crowhurst Recreation Ground, roads and gardens should ease through Wednesday and Thursday. The Combe Haven through Bulverhythe will continue to rise 20cm each high tide, but each peak will now be slightly lower than the last. Bexhill Road Recreation Ground in Bulverhythe will remain affected by flood water, potentially until next week. Very little rain is forecast for the next five days. River levels should continue to slowly fall, returning nearer to normal in Crowhurst by Thursday, but will not fall significantly in Bulverhythe until next week. River levels will remain sensitive to future rain. Please remain prepared for more periods of flood risk this winter. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this Flood Alert if the risk of flooding increases.

The River Adur is higher than normal, but slowly falling following Tuesday's rain. Minor flooding could continue to affect fields and roads between Coolham and Henfield while the river returns to normal. Very little rain is forecast for the next five days. The river should have fallen as far as it will go by Thursday 14/12/2023. Some roads, including the Coolham road at Slaughter Bridge, could still be affected by some flood water. Please take care driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this Flood Alert if the risk of flooding increases.

There is no further significant rain forecast over the next few days, therefore, levels should gradually fall throughout the week. This process will be slowed down by the rising tides. The Jubilee Bridge flood gates (Wood Lane crossing of River Don) remain open. 
 
Please stay away from flood embankments and do not walk or drive through flood water. We will continue to monitor the forecast and river levels closely. This message will be updated by 06:00 PM on 13/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels are high in response to recent heavy rainfall. Flooding is expected on the Hundred Foot (Ouse) Washes for several days. This information is correct as of 3pm on 13/12/23. The causeway at Earith currently has water on the road. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 64cm of water on the road. The causeway at Welney currently has approximately 65cm of water on the road. Norfolk County Council have closed Welney causeway. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. Floodwater is travelling down the River Great Ouse towards the Ouse Washes which will keep levels high for several days. Avoid driving through floodwater. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 8am tomorrow, 14/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Dean, Singleton, Charlton, East Dean and Chilgrove
items.message: Above average rainfall has been measured in October, November and December 2023. Groundwater is high, within a few centimetres of the surface in East Dean, and still rising. Minor groundwater flood impacts are expected to continue, with springs appearing, water flowing on roads, water in basements or under floorboards, and affecting the ability of the sewage network to operate in East Dean, Charlton, Singleton and West Dean. A small amount of water could also flow down the B2141 at Chilgrove. Very little rainfall is forecast for the next five days, however groundwater will continue rising until at least 17/12/2023 at the Chilgrove borehole. Flood impacts are expected to remain until at least the middle of January, and potentially longer or affecting more people if wet weather returns. Groundwater will remain higher than normal and sensitive to any additional rainfall over winter. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 20/12/2023

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors, low lying properties around Muchelney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.17m and falling. The pumping station drain level is stable at 8.52m. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.30m, from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86m, and from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93m. Property flooding is possible with this level exceeding 8.35m.

Scattered showers are forecast today, Wednesday, together with a band of light rain on Thursday morning. We expect dry weather to return for the remainder of the week. We are currently pumping at Westover and Huish Episcopi and will continue to maximise pumping activities to reduce water in the moors as and when river levels allow.

We continue to monitor rainfall, river levels and flood defence assets. Please remain mindful of weather conditions and local water levels. Do not attempt to drive, walk or cycle through flood water.
Please refer to @TravelSomerset for information on closed roads.

This message will be updated by midday on 14/12/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are expected to steadily fall throughout today. Further rainfall is forecast this morning, but showers should clear later today. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses as there may be standing water in some locations. This message will be updated by 7pm on Wednesday 13 December, or as the situation changes.

The Groundwater level at the Dickley Down borehole has eased back slightly to 167.8m above sea level following a very rapid rise at the end of last week. With a drier spell forecast for the week ahead, conditions should see a slight improvement, although patches of standing water will remain on roads for several days ahead. Drivers are asked to slow down when driving through even shallow water as the bow wave can cause damage to nearby properties. Driving more slowly reduces the chance that water will enter your engine, which, if it happens can cause the engine to be written off. Check that pumps and other property level resilience measures are still working correctly, and perhaps think about contingency measures should they fail.
We will continue to monitor groundwater levels in your area and this message will be updated on Thursday 14th December or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the South Winterbourne Valley
items.message:
The level at Kingston Russell borehole has risen once more, although the rate of rise is now slowing. The level at 121.36m above sea level is the highest ever recorded at this location, however as this has been achieved over several weeks the impact will be less severe than on previous occasions, such as in 2012, when a similar level was reached within just a few days. Householders with pumps and other property level resilience measures should ensure that they are operating correctly and should make contingency plans against their failure. 
Avoid driving through flood water as  this can put your life and that of emergency responders at risk. The bow wave from vehicles can damage adjacent properties.
This message will be updated on Thursday the 14th December or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Devils Brook
items.message: Groundwater levels at the Dickley Down borehole have fallen back slightly overnight to 167.8 metres above sea level whilst the level at nearby Doles Ash has risen 10cm to 122.91 metres. Levels at both are expected to drop back over the next week in line with the forecast drier spell. Many local roads will be flooded for sometime and motorists are asked to drive slowly through these as the bow wave created by vehicles can cause damage to nearby properties. Driving slowly reduces the risk of water being taken up into the engine. Sewage systems are are likely to be impacted for some time. This message will be updated on Thursday 14th December or as the situation changes.

The River Ems is high, following a wet autumn, but is now stable. Very little rain is forecast in the next five days. River levels will not fall far. Minimal flood impacts affecting small areas of fields, rural roads and gardens in Westbourne and Emsworth will likely remain. However, flood risk is not expected to increase. The river will be sensitive to any additional rainfall over the rest of winter. Please keep flood protection products to hand in Westbourne and Emsworth, if you have them. We are operating our structure at Constant Springs and clearing grilles to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will re-issue this Flood Alert if the weather forecast has enough rain to potentially increase flood risk.

The water level in the upper River Meon remains very high, but it is now falling. For the next 5 days, the weather should be fairly dry. This will give the river a chance to lower. Out of bank flood impacts to low lying land will persist for several days, but the situation should slowly improve.

items.description: Upper River Colne and Radlett Brook

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Piddle Valley
items.message: Groundwater levels at the Doles Ash borehole have risen to 122.91 metres above sea level. Some property flooding as well as disruption to the road and sewer networks is expected, however, as a spell of drier weather moves in over the next week, conditions may show a slight improvement.  Home owners with property level resilience measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers should check that they are working correctly, and consider what contingency measures that they could employ in the event of a failure. Avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave from vehicles can damage adjacent properties. Stay out of flood water which is hazardous to you and emergency service staff who may have to rescue you. This message will be updated on Thursday 14th December or as the situation changes.

The water level in the lower River Meon remains very high, but it is now falling. For the next 5 days, the weather should be fairly dry. This will give the river a chance to lower. Out of bank flood impacts to low lying land will persist for several weeks, especially in the fields at Titchfield Hill, but the situation should slowly improve.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in upper River Ems Valley
items.message: October and November 2023 have been exceptionally wet. Nearly a month's rainfall (80mm) has been recorded this week. Groundwater is high, close to the surface, and rising. From 13/12/2023 minor groundwater flood impacts are possible, with springs and minor flooding affecting fields, the village green at Stoughton, and rural roads including Stoughton main road, the road from East Marden and also between Cooks Lane and The Barley Mow, and the B2146 near Woodlands Lane, in Walderton. Showers are forecast Sunday, Monday and Wednesday, with a further 25mm of rain is forecast for Tuesday 12/12/2023. Groundwater is expected to continue rising until at least 17/12/2023. If dry weather returns, groundwater flood impacts might ease in January 2024. However, groundwater will remain higher than normal and sensitive to any additional rainfall, with flood risk possible over the winter. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 15/12/2023

The forecast is for continued unsettled weather over the next couple of days. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. October and November 2023 have been exceptionally wet. Nearly a month's rainfall (75mm) has been recorded this week. Groundwater is high, close to the surface, and rising. From 13/12/2023 minor groundwater flood impacts are possible. Water could begin to appear in a small number of basements. Previous events suggest impacts may initially affect Old London Road, Patcham and Peacock Lane, Withdean. Sunday and Monday are forecast to remain mostly dry. Another 10-20mm of rain is forecast for Tuesday 12/12/2023. Groundwater could continue rising until 16/12/2023 at Ladies Mile borehole, and a few days after in Patcham. Drier weather is possible towards the end of the week. Groundwater flood impacts might ease by the last week in December. However, groundwater will remain higher than normal and sensitive to any additional rainfall over winter. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We will continue to monitor levels and forecasts and liaise with Brighton and Hove City Council. We will update this message by 18:00 15/12/2023.

items.description: North Bank Road alongside the River Nene, east of Peterborough and west of Dog-in-a-Doublet Sluice
items.message: River levels remain high in the Peterborough area following persistent rainfall.  During periods of high tide the river Nene will be unable to discharge into the sea, resulting in tide lock conditions.  Whilst this flood warning remains in force, the local authority will close North Bank Road and diversionary routes will be in place and further updates will be available through the local media. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by 16:00 on 13/12/23, or before, if the situation changes.

Whilst the Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority may close the B1040 for safety reasons. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media. items.message:
River levels are high but steady throughout today (Wednesday 13 December) as rainfall eases.
Further rainfall showers are expected this morning, but these should clear throughout the day.
No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 14/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

The River Arun is high, but currently stable at Pulborough. A lot of rain fell Tuesday. River levels at Pulborough are expected to rise through Wednesday and into Thursday 14/12/2023. Water will continue to be extensive through fields. From 14:00 13/12/2023 flood water could approach properties on Lower Street and Swan Corner, Pulborough. Water will also be close to Bridge Cottages, Greatham. For a few hours after each high tide, for the rest of the week, water levels will be very similar to those experienced Monday and Tuesday at Houghton Bridge, Amberley and Arundel, with water close to the top of the banks. Very little rain is forecast for the next five days. Flood risk in Pulborough is not expected to reduce until Friday 15/12/2023. Water levels will remain higher than normal until next week. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed as a precaution, in Pulborough, Amberley and Arundel, if you have them. Our pumps in Pulborough are running to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will update this message by 22:00 13/12/2023.

items.description: River Severn at Court Meadow, Kempsey and Callow End
items.message:
River levels are currently high at the Kempsey Yacht Club river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect Court Meadow Caravan Park. 
A predicted peak level of 6.0m to 6.3m on Friday afternoon, 15/12/23. 
Flood water could be deep and fast flowing, and therefore pose a risk to life. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours, and we are closely monitoring the situation. This warning may be re-issued if river levels begin rising again. Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services and Local Authorities. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and move possession and valuables off the ground or to safety. 
This message will be updated by 6pm on 13/12/23, or as the situation changes
This flood warning has been removed due to river levels falling back below levels of concern. We continue to monitor the forecast and will reissue this flood warning if necessary.

River levels remain high on the lower River Wharfe following rainfall in the upper catchment, but are falling slowly. Flooding continues to be possible around locations near the River Wharfe, with low-lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around properties on Main Street in Ryther and on Boggart Lane in Ozendyke. 
River levels are expected to fall throughout Wednesday 13/12/2023. Our incident room is open and we are closely monitoring river levels and rainfall. We have deployed pumping equipment and staff to manage levels. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 18:00hrs on Wednesday 13/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message:
A series of high tides is expected over the next few days. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Severn from Sandhurst to Chepstow and Sharpness. High tides may also affect watercourses draining into the Severn Estuary. Predicted Peaks:
Sandhurst 3.4m to 3.8m at 10:15pm on 13/12/2023 and 3.4m to 3.9m at 10:30am on 14/12/2023;
Gloucester 3.2 to 3.6m at 9:30pm on 13/12/2023 and 3.2 to 3.8m at 10:00am on 14/12/2023.
Flooding is not currently expected in other gauge locations. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation.
This message will be updated by 12pm on 14/12/2023 or if the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Torksey river gauge as a result of high tides coinciding with high river levels. Flooding is possible on high tides today and overnight. Areas most at risk are the A57 Dunham Road Bridge at Dunham-on-Trent. Property is not expected to flood at this stage.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 16:00 today, 13/12/23 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Parrett (lower) at Langport Westover Trading Estate
items.message:
Water levels are now slowly falling on the moors outside Langport. The current level in the Westover Pumping Station Drain is 8.05m. The southern end of Westover Trading Estate Road will flood when this level exceeds 8.10m, and properties on the Trading Estate flood if water levels reach 8.35m AOD. Other areas at risk if levels rise further include Cheapside, Whatley Mews, Parrett Close, Bow Street and Moor Park.

Scattered showers are forecast today, Wednesday, together with a band of light rain on Thursday morning. We expect dry weather to return for the remainder of the week. We are currently pumping at Westover and Huish Episcopi and will continue to maximise pumping activities, to clear the moors, as far as river levels allow.

Please be mindful of weather conditions, local water levels, and flood plans. Do not attempt to drive or walk through flood water. Please refer to @TravelSomerset for information on closed roads.

This message will be updated by midday on 14/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in villages surrounding Andover
items.message: Groundwater levels in the villages surrounding Andover are high and rising. In the last 2 months, prolonged, much higher than average rainfall (322mm) was recorded in Andover. At Clanville Gate, the rate of rise is slow, at 10cm per day. We expect groundwater to be impacting the sewer network at Penton Mewsey and the main road at Penton Grafton is expected to be impacted by flooding within the next few days. Groundwater will emerge in many of the ditches and roads in most villages. It is possible that a very small number of cellars will be affected in Appleshaw from Friday 15/12/2023. From Wednesday 13/12/2023 to Monday 18/12/2023 the weather is expected to become drier, however we expect levels to continue to rise for at least the next 7 days. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please remove any valuables stored in cellars. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure they can operate. This message will be updated by 17:00 on Tuesday 19/12/2023.

In Hursley, groundwater levels are high and rising. In the last 2 months, prolonged, much higher than average rainfall (381mm) was recorded at our rain gauge in Otterbourne. In the last 24 hours, the groundwater level has increased by 19cm. At the current rate of rise, cellar flooding is possible from Thursday 14/12/2023 at the southern end of the village at South End Close. From Saturday 16/12/2023, cellar flooding could occur at the Dolphin Inn Pub and impacts to the sewage network could be experienced. From Wednesday 13/12/2023 to Monday 18/12/2023 the weather is expected to be drier, however levels are still expected to rise for at least another week. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This message will be updated at 17:00 on Tuesday 19/12/2023.
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. Further showers are forecast over the next few days. We will continue to monitor the situation and will re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.description: River Darent from Westerham to Dartford
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels are remaining high, but steady on the River Darent due to heavy rainfall yesterday, 12/12/23. Flooding of roads and low lying land near the river remains a possibility until tomorrow afternoon, 14/12/23. Flooding to property is not currently expected. Further light, intermittent rainfall is forecasted for today, 13/12/23, before turning dry tomorrow, 14/12/23. We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow morning, 14/12/23. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. 
This message will be updated by 9pm tonight, 13/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

The River Arun is high but falling between Horsham and Rudgwick. Through Wednesday minor impacts affecting fields, roads and gardens in Tanbridge and Blackbridge Court, behind Arunside and isolated properties at Broadbridge Heath and Wanford, will slowly ease as the river level falls. Near Billingshurst and Pallingham Lock, river levels are still slowly rising and could rise another 20cm, and come closer to properties at Pallingham Lock, before beginning to fall from 17:00 Wednesday afternoon 13/12/2023. Very little rain is forecast for the next five days. River levels should return nearer to normal by Thursday near Horsham and by Friday 15/12/2023 near to Pallingham Lock. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Wanford, if you have them. Our automatic sluice at Provender Mill is operating to help reduce the risk of flooding through Horsham. We will update this message by 14:00 14/12/2023.

Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible today 13/12/23, especially in the areas around Shiplake and Wargrave. Further showers are forecast today 13/12/23, although significant rainfall is not expected. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

The River Lox is high but now falling following Tuesday's rain. Through Wednesday 13/12/2023, minor flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads and gardens along the length of the river Lox, including near Brewhurst Mill on Brewhurst Lane and at the Onslow Arms, Loxwood. Very little rain is forecast for the next five days. River levels will slowly fall through Wednesday, returning nearer to normal by Thursday afternoon 14/12/2023. River levels will remain sensitive to additional rainfall over the next few weeks. Please continue to operate private water control structures at Brewhurst, to reduce the risk of flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this Flood Alert if the risk of flooding increases.

River levels remain high at the Bredwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye from Hay on Wye to Ross on Wye. Other locations that may be affected include the A438, Byford, Bredwardine and Hereford. 
Updated predicted and actual peaks:- Hay on Wye peaked at 2.12m on Tuesday evening, Bredwardine peaked at 4.02m early Wednesday morning, Belmont is predicted to peak between 4.0m to 4.1m on Wednesday morning, Old Wye Bridge is predicted to peak between 3.6m to 3.7m on Wednesday morning, Mordiford is predicted to peak between 3.9m to 4.1m on Wednesday morning, Ross on Wye is predicted to peak between 3.6m to 3.8m on Wednesday evening.
We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00, 14/12/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Mordiford river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye.
Predicted Peaks:- Ross on Wye 3.6m to 3.8m on Wednesday evening.
We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Home owners with property level resilience measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers should check that they are in place and working properly. items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Meon Valley from East Meon to Soberton
items.message: In the Meon Valley, groundwater levels are high and rising. In the last 2 months, prolonged, much higher than average rainfall (451mm) was recorded in Warnford. The winterbourne has been flowing in Meonstoke for several weeks and there is a small amount of water ponded around the electricity sub-station in Rectory Lane. The weather from today (13/12/2023) until Sunday (17/12/2023) is forecast to be dry. At our borehole at Pound Lane, the groundwater level will stabilise by Friday 15/12/2023, before beginning to slowly fall. Long range forecasting is difficult, but there is currently an indication that unsettled weather will return to Hampshire from the end of next week. If heavy rain affects the Meon Valley, groundwater levels will rise again, and water will begin flowing across Rectory Lane. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Tuesday 19/12/2023.
